Neutron is refactoring a lot of its code. For example, common entities
are being moved to neutron-lib. When code is refactored it is marked
with debtcollector, which issues a deprecation warning. In the next

'}]
commit_message:
Enable DeprecationWarning in test environments

Neutron is refactoring a lot of its code. For example, common entities
are being moved to neutron-lib. When code is refactored it is marked
with debtcollector, which issues a deprecation warning. In the next
release the old entity will be removed. Consuming projects (like
tricircle) must update to comply with the new entity before the old
one is removed.

Tricircle maintainers must monitor deprecation warnings and act on them
before the next release.

Many deprecations are triggered early (on imports, for example)
before the warnings are enabled by the WarningsFixture in the
base test class.

To make sure all DeprecationWarning messages are emitted we enable
them via the PYTHONWARNINGS environment variable.

Change-Id: Iade909b35a55cebb7dfe13a688f451ad91989b94
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tricircle refs/changes/92/353192/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: PYTHONWARNINGS=default::DeprecationWarning

commit_message:
Remove '--config' option when create/update a vim

When create/update a vim, only enable '--config-file' option, will
remove '--config' option.

Change-Id: I8a728134ce0229db98de10bff5f4f46e7f2a9f2c
Closes-bug: #1587216

uploaded.

This reverts commit 075358c04a348219f5dfa54c6f9d95600dd8168c.

commit_message:
Move other-requirements.txt to bindep.txt

The default filename for documenting binary dependencies has been
changed from "other-requirements.txt" to "bindep.txt" with the release
of bindep 2.1.0. While the previous name is still supported, it will
be deprecated.

Move the file around to follow this change.

Note that this change is self-testing, the OpenStack CI infrastructure
will use a "bindep.txt" file to setup nodes for testing.

For more information about bindep, see also:
http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#package-requirements
http://docs.openstack.org/infra/bindep/

As well as this announcement:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-August/101590.html

Change-Id: If909bfc3696619d16ba87591c4e6a831f63f20ff

commit_message:
Fix node join behavior

When adding a node to a cluster, we need to set the node index before
updating the backend physical resource. In this way, the backend
resource (e.g. a nova server) can always get a reasonable index value.
This is a preparation for updating server metadata properly.

Change-Id: Ic25d5655bf823b35280adfb870784a49289d3c88
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/01/356301/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Don't fail if switch is not found

This patch allows to do not fail immediately if switch is not found in
genericswitch devices. It allows neutron to use other ML2 drivers/agents
try to bind port.

Change-Id: If03a5c7f6cbad00bac297abea10bfd9707cbee46

commit_message:
Configure tempest to run the auto_allocated_topology tests

This sets the feature toggle in tempest for testing the
auto-allocated-topology API in neutron (used by nova).

Change-Id: I9448e3c737722740921703c3ea60030d584d02b7
Depends-On: Ia8538e20ba52c85cfabbf9e44a959b2821995eab

added_lines: if is_networking_extension_supported 'auto-allocated-topology'; then iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG network-feature-enabled auto_allocated_topology True fi

Ensure that lxc_container starts/stops are logged

This patch ensures that all lxc_container starts/stops are
logged in the container debug log.

commit_message:
Remove requirements.txt install for testing

These packages will already be installed as part of the swift
installation, so it is redundant to install these again.

This PR removes the redundant requirements file installation.

Change-Id: If0b1787381b388b2a1ead3dbda1b439dd55dbf6e

commit_message:
[DOCS] - Clean up role docs

 - README now links to role docs and project launchpad
 - Project homepage links to developer docs
 - Service capitalization fixed
 - Example playbook indentation fixed

commit_message:
Volume migration progress

This patch proposes the following changes:
* Get the volume migration progress for one volume.
This is an admin only action, make it possible for the
admin to check the migration progress.

DocImpact
APIImpact

Partial-implements: blueprint migration-improvement
Change-Id: I5a1a717d1d08f550b45836d958a51f1f3fba5eed

added_lines: def print_list(objs, fields, exclude_unavailable=False, formatters=None, sortby_index=0): @param exclude_unavailable: Boolean to decide if unavailable fields are removed removed_fields = [] rows = [] if exclude_unavailable and field in removed_fields: continue if not hasattr(o, field_name) and exclude_unavailable: removed_fields.append(field) continue else: data = getattr(o, field_name, '') if exclude_unavailable: rows.append(row) else: pt.add_row(row) if exclude_unavailable: for f in removed_fields: fields.remove(f) pt = prettytable.PrettyTable([f for f in fields], caching=False) pt.aligns = ['l' for f in fields] for row in rows: pt.add_row(row)
deleted_lines: def print_list(objs, fields, formatters=None, sortby_index=0): data = getattr(o, field_name, '') pt.add_row(row)

subject: Return backup parent_id when list/show backups
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-26 07:39:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/02c2b1a8b6b35246ff81f7bf7404381d25f3261e', 'message': "return backup parent_id when list/show backups

commit_message:
Return backup parent_id when list/show backups

Currently, when the details of a backup are returned when the list
backups or show backup commands are called, the parent_id is
not included. This patch adds the parent_id to the data being
returned.

This patch will make us known the dependency relationship
between a volume's backups easier.

The parent_id also help horizon or other openstack portal
to draw the backups relationship graph.

APIImpact
DocImpact

Change-Id: I575748cd12416dab45f1b7b46fa5454d6521578a
Implements: blueprint list-backups-return-parent-id

subject: Migrate remotefs from rootwrap to privsep
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-16 04:36:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-brick/commit/d0ad1b3de5ba4b2983b895056a534b4e852ee6e3', 'message': "Migrate remotefs from rootwrap to privsep

This is an initial change to introduce oslo.privsep.  As an example test
candidate, this change also migrates remotefs from rootwrap to privsep.

Since privsep works around python function calls rather than rootwrap's
command lines, the migration is not a simple substition.  The approach
taken here is that all privileged command lines are built on the
privileged side from meaningful arguments that can be verified
separately.

In addition, it is expected that a paranoid deployment of this change
will run the privileged process as a non-root uid, with CAP_SYS_ADMIN.
This non-root uid will need to be able to write to relevant filesystem
locations (eg: /etc/pstorage/clusters/ if using vzstorage), but it means
zero use of uid=0 or sudo, and file operations can be performed in
natural python rather than execing chown, tee, etc.

Change-Id: Iec56ead6d12a018fbf848d518184ba3ef3d45e9e
Implements: blueprint privsep

commit_message:
Migrate remotefs from rootwrap to privsep

This is an initial change to introduce oslo.privsep.  As an example test
candidate, this change also migrates remotefs from rootwrap to privsep.

Since privsep works around python function calls rather than rootwrap's
command lines, the migration is not a simple substition.  The approach
taken here is that all privileged command lines are built on the
privileged side from meaningful arguments that can be verified
separately.

In addition, it is expected that a paranoid deployment of this change
will run the privileged process as a non-root uid, with CAP_SYS_ADMIN.
This non-root uid will need to be able to write to relevant filesystem
locations (eg: /etc/pstorage/clusters/ if using vzstorage), but it means
zero use of uid=0 or sudo, and file operations can be performed in
natural python rather than execing chown, tee, etc.

Depends-On: I9e44952ba83abccd7130fd01a9acbb09520fdb38
Change-Id: Iec56ead6d12a018fbf848d518184ba3ef3d45e9e
Implements: blueprint privsep

Replace keystoneclient.adapter with keystoneauth1.adapter

commit_message:
Don't call remove_export with attachments left

This patch changes how Cinder responds to detach calls
for volumes that are attached to multiple VMs on a single host.

When multi-attach is enabled and a single volume is attached to
multiple vms on a single host, we don't want to call the driver's
remove_export as this will most likely remove the target and cause
failures for the remaining attachments.

Change-Id: I292304b1aa76d7cb7e04731fd0ecb902428ea224
Closes-Bug: #1471278

commit_message:
Update test cases related to attach_volume
and detach_volume API

The following patch updates test cases related to
attach_volume and detach_volume API with volume
versionedobjects in cinder/tests/unit/test_volume.py
file.

We want to update both the attach_volume()
and detach_volume() with versionedobjects.
There are 3 patches in the chain.

The patch sequence is:
- Update attach_volume() with versionedojbects
- Update detach_volume() with versionedobjects
- Update test cases related to attach_volume
  and detach_volume in file
  cinder/tests/unit/test_volume.py

Co-Authored-By: Thang Pham <thang.g.pham@gmail.com>
Partial-Implements: blueprint cinder-objects

Change-Id: I354de08b92a9d5515f354d19960b80ded530a8a8

commit_message:
Use magic constants instead of magic numbers

It's a best practice to use magic constants instead of
magic numbers. So, this patch tried to introduce the
HTTP status codes unified by the httplib to replace
the direct hard code.

Change-Id: Id00d15a331826b79e14bdce0ea7fc60e482da818
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/22/290322/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from six.moves import http_client response.status_code = http_client.INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR

commit_message:
Add judgement of backing-up volume status

Backing up in-use glusterfs volume, in fact it create
snapshot and then copy volume from snapshot to achieve
backup.And now the volume status will change to backing-up.

Backup will call _create_cloned_volume function in remotefs.py,
But _create_cloned_volume func lack judgement of backing-up
status.

Change-Id: I1e86ca42a8eb406653e3916f67c9e3337e6d9ffd
Closes-Bug: #1553447

subject: Improve the time cost for datastore selection in cinder vmdk driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-03 08:10:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/feef79a6301e2c33c43156236196211279bd6859', 'message': "Improve the time cost for datastore selection in cinder vmdk driver

The current datastore selection method in cinder vmdk driver is: get
ll the hosts, then traverse all the datastores of the hosts, this
needs API calls to get datastores of each host, when an adequate
datastore is selected, the loop and selection process will terminate.
If no datastore meets the requirement, it will traverse all the hosts.

So if there are many hosts in the environment, and the top hosts in
the host list don't meet the requirement, openstack will keep
traversing and interactiving with the next host, the result is
openstack interactives too much times with vcenter(api calls).
If the user is going to do an operation, for example: create a volume,
it will be very slow to create a volume, it's an potential
performance problem.

Through investigation, the time cost mainly focuses on datastore
selection phase, so this commit aims to improve the performance
problem during datastore selection.

Change-Id: I774ae2b2f1a94aff49a2ac47e2b536379d5e73af

commit_message:
Improve the time cost for datastore selection in cinder vmdk driver

The current datastore selection method in cinder vmdk driver is: get
all the hosts, then iterate over all the datastores of the hosts, this
needs API calls to get datastores of each host, when an adequate
datastore is selected, the loop and selection process will terminate.
If no datastore meets the requirement, it will iterate over all the
hosts.

So if there are many hosts in the environment, and the top hosts in
the host list don't meet the requirement, openstack will keep
iterating and interactiving with the next host, the result is
openstack interactives too much times with vcenter(api calls).
If the user is going to do an operation, for example: create a volume,
it will be very slow to create a volume, it's an potential
performance problem.

Through investigation, the time cost mainly focuses on datastore
selection phase, so this commit aims to improve the performance
problem during datastore selection.

Change-Id: I774ae2b2f1a94aff49a2ac47e2b536379d5e73af
Closes-Bug: #1521894
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/10/252810/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import random # Since the accessed order of hosts collection won't change each time, # so make a random order for the hosts collection here, to improve the # time cost on datastore selection, and avoid the same datastore is # always selected random.shuffle(hosts)

commit_message:
Add pagination support to cgsnapshots

In liberty release, we have added pagination to backups
and snapshots. There are still some work that hasn't been
done yet.
This patch adds pagination support to cgsnapshots.

APIImpact
Add pagination args like limit, marker, sort to query
cgsnapshots.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I84e0b8bce744d036c435fb57c29889ba3a605b90
Implements: blueprint add-pagination-to-other-resource

commit_message:
Sheepdog: Improve copy_volume_to_image method

Since cinder has provided image_utils.convert_image() method to
convert image, I think it's better to use this method instead of
run qemu-img command directly.

Change-Id: I16bc9a2b3666a080710c335bb9ed843e9cd91d8f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/04/249804/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # convert and store sheepdog image into tmp file image_utils.convert_image( 'sheepdog:%(addr)s:%(port)d:%(name)s' % { 'addr': CONF.sheepdog_store_address, 'port': CONF.sheepdog_store_port, 'name': volume['name']}, tmp, 'raw')
deleted_lines: # image_utils.convert_image doesn't support "sheepdog:" source, # so we use the qemu-img directly. # Sheepdog volume is always raw-formatted. cmd = ('qemu-img', 'convert', '-f', 'raw', '-t', 'none', '-O', 'raw', 'sheepdog:%s' % volume['name'], tmp) self._try_execute(*cmd)

commit_message:
Encode the url parameters for XIO driver

Many URI include components consisting of or delimited by, certain
special characters.  These characters are called "reserved", since
their usage within the URI component is limited to their reserved
purpose.  If the data for a URI component would conflict with the
reserved purpose, then the conflicting data must be escaped before
forming the URI.

  reserved = ";" | "/" | "?" | ":" | "@" | "&" | "=" | "+" |
           "$" | ","

refs:
  http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2396.txt
  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4667942/why-should-i-use-urlencode

Change-Id: I40ee5af9553af8ebb15558a2f89b247c83d79cff
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/57/254157/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: params = [(name, value) for name, value in params.items() if value != ''] return urllib.parse.urlencode(params)
deleted_lines: param_str = [] for name, value in params.items(): if value != '': param_str.append("%s=%s" % (name, value)) return '&'.join(param_str)

"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-12-01 22:33:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/7ccd5303834a29b5e46f6ea27999b6ae282385c8', 'message': "All Cinder LVM operations run with LVM_SYSTEM_DIR

Up to now only a subset of LVM commands (pvs, vgs, lvs & lvdisplay)
ran with an appropriate LVM_SYSTEM_DIR value set in their environment,
based upon the lvm_conf_file config option.

As a result this meant that the /etc/lvm/lvm.conf file still had to
permit scanning of the devices providing the LVM PVs backing Cinder's
Volume Groups. Which of course means that Cinder and the host system's
LVM operations were not truly isolated from each other.

This has now been rectified by ensuring that all LVM commands are run
with an appropriate LVM_SYSTEM_DIR environment setting.

All LVM commands are constructed as a cmd list prior to being passed
to the _lvm() or lvm_cmd() methods.

Updated the etc/cinder/rootwrap.d/volume.filters entries for all the
LVM commands to reflect this; they now use the EnvFilter rather than
CommandFilter. Removed redundant _lvmconf filter entries.

Affected unit tests, such as those for Brick LVM, have been updated
to work with this new model.

Upgrade Impact:
===============
There shouldn't be any impact on upgrade as a result of this patch.

If no lvm_conf_file was previously specified in cinder.conf then
before and after this change the system default lvm.conf file,
e.g. /etc/lvm/lvm.conf, will have been used.

If an lvm_conf_file was previously specified, and it used filtering
to limit the set of devices scanned to only those devices that Cinder
should be targeting, then previously the effect of that filtering
would have been limited to the show/display commands, whereas now
all Cinder generated LVM commands will limited to seeing only the
specified devices; this shouldn't cause problems since Cinder LVM
commands shouldn't be trying to access other devices on the system
anyway.

The only way I foresee this change having an upgrade impact is if
the tooling used to test the upgrade were to implement filtering
in the system lvm.conf file such that system lvm commands ignored
the Cinder devices; in that case DevStack would likely fail because
it wouldn't be able to create the Cinder volume group, since it
expects to be able to do so using the system default lvm.conf
environment.

Change-Id: I9420c3d8b232367b610622d94e8923dedcc314e6
Closes-Bug: #1506220
"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2015-12-14 22:03:31.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/brick/local_dev/lvm.py', 'etc/cinder/rootwrap.d/volume.filters', 'cinder/tests/unit/brick/test_brick_lvm.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/7407a911578a0c89f7c8a8dca479d3c13846b06e', 'message': "All Cinder LVM operations run with LVM_SYSTEM_DIR

Up to now only a subset of LVM commands (pvs, vgs, lvs & lvdisplay)
ran with an appropriate LVM_SYSTEM_DIR value set in their environment,
based upon the lvm_conf_file config option.

As a result this meant that the /etc/lvm/lvm.conf file still had to
permit scanning of the devices providing the LVM PVs backing Cinder's
Volume Groups. Which of course means that the host and Cinder LVM
operations were not truly isolated from each other.

This has now been rectified by ensuring that all LVM commands are run
with an appropriate LVM_SYSTEM_DIR environment setting.

All LVM commands are constructed as a cmd list prior to being passed
to the _lvm() method or lvm_cmd() staticmethod.

Updated the etc/cinder/rootwrap.d/volume.filters entries for all the
LVM commands to reflect this; they now use the EnvFilter rather than
CommandFilter. Removed redundant _lvmconf filter entries.

Affected unit tests, such as those for Brick LVM, have been updated
to work with this new model.

Notes with regard to Upgrades:
==============================
There shouldn't be any impact on upgrade as a result of this patch
unless a pre-existing effort has been made to fully isolate the host
LVM environment from the Cinder LVM environment by having the host
/etc/lvm/lvm.conf file ignore the devices that will be backing the
Cinder LVM VGs.

However, given that this patch is intended to fix the issues that
prevented the deployment of a system with true isolation of the
host and Cinder LVM environments, I don't believe there is likely
to be any upgrade impact.

If no lvm_conf_file is specified in cinder.conf then before and
after this change any Cinder LVM commands will have been using the
system default lvm.conf file.

If an lvm_conf_file was previously specified, and it used filtering
to limit the set of devices scanned to only those devices that
Cinder should be targeting, then the effect would have been limited
to the show/display commands, whereas now all Cinder generated
LVM commands will be affected. This shouldn't cause problems since
Cinder LVM commands shouldn't be trying to access other devices on
the system anyway.

Change-Id: I9420c3d8b232367b610622d94e8923dedcc314e6
Closes-Bug: #1506220
UpgradeImpact
"}]
commit_message:
All Cinder LVM operations run with LVM_SYSTEM_DIR

Up to now only a subset of LVM commands (pvs, vgs, lvs & lvdisplay)
ran with an appropriate LVM_SYSTEM_DIR value set in their environment,
based upon the lvm_conf_file config option.

As a result this meant that the /etc/lvm/lvm.conf file still had to
permit scanning of the devices providing the LVM PVs backing Cinder's
Volume Groups. Which of course means that the host and Cinder LVM
operations were not truly isolated from each other.

This has now been rectified by ensuring that all LVM commands are run
with an appropriate LVM_SYSTEM_DIR environment setting.

All LVM commands are constructed as a cmd list prior to being passed
to the _lvm() method or lvm_cmd() staticmethod.

Updated the etc/cinder/rootwrap.d/volume.filters entries for all the
LVM commands to reflect this; they now use the EnvFilter rather than
CommandFilter. Removed redundant _lvmconf filter entries.

Affected unit tests, such as those for Brick LVM, have been updated
to work with this new model.

Notes with regard to Upgrades:
==============================
There shouldn't be any impact on upgrade as a result of this patch
unless a pre-existing effort has been made to fully isolate the host
LVM environment from the Cinder LVM environment by having the host
/etc/lvm/lvm.conf file ignore the devices that will be backing the
Cinder LVM VGs.

However, given that this patch is intended to fix the issues that
prevented the deployment of a system with true isolation of the
host and Cinder LVM environments, I don't believe there is likely
to be any upgrade impact.

If no lvm_conf_file is specified in cinder.conf then before and
after this change any Cinder LVM commands will have been using the
system default lvm.conf file.

If an lvm_conf_file was previously specified, and it used filtering
to limit the set of devices scanned to only those devices that
Cinder should be targeting, then the effect would have been limited
to the show/display commands, whereas now all Cinder generated
LVM commands will be affected. This shouldn't cause problems since
Cinder LVM commands shouldn't be trying to access other devices on
the system anyway.

Change-Id: I9420c3d8b232367b610622d94e8923dedcc314e6
Closes-Bug: #1506220
UpgradeImpact

If a volume driver crashes in initialize_connection(), the single-argument
invocation of "raise" dropped the original backtrace, leaving this line
as the last hint to what went wrong.

This is clearly non-optimal; debugging is much easier if the correct

commit_message:
Show the original backtrace for failures in initialize_connection()

If a volume driver crashes in initialize_connection(), the single-argument
invocation of "raise" dropped the original backtrace, leaving this line
as the last hint to what went wrong.

This is clearly non-optimal; debugging is much easier if the correct
location gets pointed out.


So, use the 3-argument version, and re-use the original backtrace.

Change-Id: Ib887b1d061c67b65a0d5e2545940a8d9f635a959
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/57/252957/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import sys raise(exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data=err_msg), None, sys.exc_info()[2])

commit_message:
Add CGSnapshotStatus enum field

This change adds a new enum and field, CGSnapshotStatus and
CGSnapshotStatusField, that will hold the constants for
the 'status' field of the CGSnapshot object. This enum and
field are based off the base oslo.versionedobjects enum
and field. This also changes over the CGSnapshot object
to use the new field (and bumps the version so newer
versions know to enforce valid values). Finally all
uses of strings for comparison and assignment to this
field are changed over to use the constants defined
within the enum.

Change-Id: I5efc30a43e82ec1990d3378e90988d0d73dc5198
Implements: bp cinder-object-fields

commit_message:
Parse filter item "name" correctly for snapshot-list

Use non-admin user, cinderclient will parse filter item
"name" to "display_name" when get snapshot list via v2 api,
this will make cinder remove the filter as an invalid filter
item and return the full snapshot list, so parse the "name"
to "name" will fix the problem.

Change-Id: I94439b082bf6ad56d3e84d3301e1869343ceae55
Closes-Bug: #1554538

commit_message:
Print a more readable output of upload-to-image

when we print a large dict of the detail of volume type in
output of upload-to-image, that's not readable at all.

Instead of outputing a confusing output, this commit makes
upload-to-image only print volume type id. That makes the
output much better.

Closes-Bug: #1557486
Change-Id: Ia2f29fa39a80aec2289775d6efd45f434653e5a0

subject: Allow triggering cleanup from API
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-07 18:22:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/9f4e12b7a0fc40121fe1172ed8874614b7941956', 'message': 'Allow triggering cleanup from API

Now that we support having multiple c-vol nodes serving the same storage
backend under one "host", they no longer clean all resources from that
host on start, only those from their own node.  So we need a way to
trigger the cleanup of the resources that were being processed by a
failed node.

This patch adds a new API endpoint (/workers/cleanup) that will trigger
cleanup for c-vol nodes.

The cleanup will be performed by other nodes that share the same host,
so at least one of them must be up to be able to do the cleanup.

Cleanup cannot be triggered during a cloud upgrade, but a restarted node
will still cleanup it's own resources during an upgrade.

If no arguments are provided cleanup will issue a clean message for all
nodes that are down, but we can restrict which nodes we want to be
cleaned using parameters `service_id`, `host`, `binary`, `node_id`,
`disabled`, `name`.

Cleaning specific resources is also possible using `resource_type` and
`resource_id` parameters.

We can even force cleanup on nodes that are up with `is_up`, but that's
not recommended.

API will return a dictionary with 2 lists, one with nodes that have been
issued a cleanup request (`cleaning`) and another list with nodes that
cannot be cleaned right now because there is no alternative node to do
the cleanup in that host (`unavailable`).

Data returned for each node in the lists is the same as the summary list
of nodes: `id`, `name` and `state`.

Specs: https://review.openstack.org/236977
Patch in series: 5/7

APIImpact: New /workers/cleanup entry
Implements: blueprint cinder-volume-active-active-support
Change-Id: Ide615714e5179e40242fdb639432c7dd393fb7e7

commit_message:
Allow triggering cleanup from API

Now that we support having multiple c-vol nodes serving the same storage
backend under one "host", they no longer clean all resources from that
host on start, only those from their own node.  So we need a way to
trigger the cleanup of the resources that were being processed by a
failed node.

This patch adds a new API endpoint (/workers/cleanup) that will trigger
cleanup for c-vol nodes as microversion 3.3.

The cleanup will be performed by other nodes that share the same host,
so at least one of them must be up to be able to do the cleanup.

Cleanup cannot be triggered during a cloud upgrade, but a restarted node
will still cleanup it's own resources during an upgrade.

If no arguments are provided cleanup will issue a clean message for all
nodes that are down, but we can restrict which nodes we want to be
cleaned using parameters `service_id`, `host`, `binary`, `node_id`,
`disabled`, `name`.

Cleaning specific resources is also possible using `resource_type` and
`resource_id` parameters.

We can even force cleanup on nodes that are up with `is_up`, but that's
not recommended.

API will return a dictionary with 2 lists, one with nodes that have been
issued a cleanup request (`cleaning`) and another list with nodes that
cannot be cleaned right now because there is no alternative node to do
the cleanup in that host (`unavailable`).

Data returned for each node in the lists is the same as the summary list
of nodes: `id`, `name` and `state`.

Specs: https://review.openstack.org/236977
Patch in series: 5/7

APIImpact: New /workers/cleanup entry
Implements: blueprint cinder-volume-active-active-support
Change-Id: Ide615714e5179e40242fdb639432c7dd393fb7e7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/22/303022/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Make c-bak use workers table for cleanup

To be able to support multiple nodes working with the same resources we
have added the workers table to keep track of which node is working with
each specific resource.

This patch makes c-bak service work with this new table by adding
entries on cleanable operations and removing them once these operations
have completed.

Service cleanup on initialization has also been changed to use this new
table so nodes will cleanup only resources from operations they left on
the air and leave any operations that are being processed by other nodes.

Backup nodes have been traditionally tightly coupled to volume nodes,
and though we now have the possibility to scale out backups
independently of volumes we may still force backups only to work if the
backup and volume services are on the same node.

And it's for this case, where we have them in the same node as we used
to, that we need c-bak to also support the workers mechanism, because we
can deploy c-vol in HA A-A fashion together with c-bak.

Specs: https://review.openstack.org/236977
Patch in series: 6/7

APIImpact: `/workers/cleanup` now accepts "Backup" as resource_type
Implements: blueprint cinder-volume-active-active-support
Change-Id: Iadc26f20cdfea52d074723a46ec1e5f59853937e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/23/303023/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CLEANABLE_RESOURCE_TYPES = ('Volume', 'Snapshot', 'Backup')

subject: Add auto cleanup mechanism
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-07 18:22:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/1796b91228aa1d410c4e415a67765682443ffde8', 'message': 'Add auto cleanup mechanism

When working in Active-Active configurations nodes may go down, and we
may want those nodes to be automatically cleaned.

This patch adds this functionality to do auto cleanup on nodes that go
down after a specific number of seconds have elapsed since the last
heartbeat of the node.

The number of seconds is defined as a multiple of `service_down_time`
with `auto_cleanup_checks` configuration option.

Even if this functionality is disabled by default we can easily enable
it with configuration option `auto_cleanup_enabled` or we can manually
trigger it using new API entry point `/workers/auto_cleanup`.

In the same way that the `/workers/cleanup` does, this new API will
return a dictionary with a list of nodes that are going to be cleaned
(`cleaning` key) and a list of nodes that cannot be cleaned because
there is no other node in the host that can do the cleaning
(`unavailable` key).

Data returned for each node in the lists is the same as the summary list
of nodes: `id`, `name` and `state`.

Specs: https://review.openstack.org/236977
Patch in series: 7/7

           enable_auto_cleanup

commit_message:
Add auto cleanup mechanism

When working in Active-Active configurations nodes may go down, and we
may want those nodes to be automatically cleaned.

This patch adds this functionality to do auto cleanup on nodes that go
down after a specific number of seconds have elapsed since the last
heartbeat of the node.

The number of seconds is defined as a multiple of `service_down_time`
with `auto_cleanup_checks` configuration option.

Even if this functionality is disabled by default we can easily enable
it with configuration option `auto_cleanup_enabled` or we can manually
trigger it using new API entry point `/workers/auto_cleanup` with
microversion 3.4.

In the same way that the `/workers/cleanup` does, this new API will
return a dictionary with a list of nodes that are going to be cleaned
(`cleaning` key) and a list of nodes that cannot be cleaned because
there is no other node in the host that can do the cleaning
(`unavailable` key).

Data returned for each node in the lists is the same as the summary list
of nodes: `id`, `name` and `state`.

Specs: https://review.openstack.org/236977
Patch in series: 7/7

APIImpact: New /worker/auto_cleanup entry
DocImpact: New configuration options: auto_cleanup_checks and
           enable_auto_cleanup
Implements: blueprint cinder-volume-active-active-support
Change-Id: Ib0f04b7d7bf85bc97dc9773bfdb0b082e18f0b08

commit_message:
After pool is introduced, cinder should support compatible

After pool is introduced in the BP "pool-aware-cinder-scheduler",
if the driver has not supported it, In the process, the backend
name is specified as the pool name.But if the driver later
implemented it, pool name is the back-end driver reported.
The scheme: when start volume service, we can get all
volumes by the host, then extract pool information from
volume's host. If the pool is None or volume_backend_name,
we call get_pool query the pool_name from driver, then
modify the volume's host information.

Closes-Bug: #1574503

Change-Id: I8b7ccad17ed002273a9475140edc93567c6ba73e

commit_message:
Make Nova API version configurable

Nova API version is hard-coded in Cinder code. It should be
configurable.

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint make-nova-api-version-configurable

commit_message:
DB: Optimize snapshot existence check

When checking for the existence of a snapshot, don't
perform a joined load which pulls much more data
than is needed.

This code mirrors the way this is implemented for
volume queries.

Related-Bug: #1579903

Change-Id: I52ef7b4d6b224c53d2ea33ab6c1a267da789ac28

commit_message:
Add service node cleanup command

Volumes nodes will perform cleanup on start, but when we have multiple
volume nodes grouped under the same host we may want to trigger cleanup
of nodes that are down.

This patch adds command `work-clean` to trigger server cleanups and
prints service nodes that will be cleaned.

This command will only work on servers supporting API version 3.3 or
higher.

New command:

cinder work-clean [--name <node-name>] [--host <hostname>]
                  [--binary <binary>] [--service-id <service-id>]
                  [--node-id <hostname>] [--resource-id <resource-id>]
                  [--resource-type <Volume|Snapshot>]
                  [--disabled <True|true|False|false>] [--exclude-down]
                  [--include-up]

Specs: https://review.openstack.org/236977
Patch in series: 3/5

Depends-On: Ide615714e5179e40242fdb639432c7dd393fb7e7
Implements: blueprint cinder-volume-active-active-support
Change-Id: Iebcbe9c0bd77537e9bb0cc8095fc290b800937a9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/36/304236/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @utils.arg('--name', metavar='<node-name>', default=None, help='Service node name. Default=None.') @utils.arg('--host', metavar='<hostname>', default=None, help='Service host name. Default=None.') @utils.arg('--binary', metavar='<binary>', default=None, help='Service binary. Default=None.') @utils.arg('--service-id', metavar='<service-id>', default=None, help='Service id. Default=None.') @utils.arg('--node-id', metavar='<hostname>', default=None, help='Service node id. Default=None.') @utils.arg('--resource-id', metavar='<resource-id>', default=None, help='UUID of a resource to cleanup. Default=None.') @utils.arg('--resource-type', metavar='<Volume|Snapshot>', default=None, choices=('Volume', 'Snapshot'), help='Type of resource to cleanup.') @utils.arg('--disabled', metavar='<True|true|False|false>', default=None, choices=('True', 'true', 'False', 'false'), help='Filter by disabled status. Default=None.') @utils.arg('--exclude-down', dest='include_down', default=True, help="Don't send cleanup request for nodes that are down.", action='store_false') @utils.arg('--include-up', dest='include_up', default=False, help='Also send cleanup requests for nodes that are up.', action='store_true') def do_work_clean(cs, args): """Request cleanup of service nodes with optional filtering.""" if not (args.include_down or args.include_up): raise exceptions.CommandError( 'No nodes are requested for cleanup when excluding down nodes and ' 'not including up nodes.') filters = dict(host=args.host, binary=args.binary, service_id=args.service_id, node_id=args.node_id, resource_id=args.resource_id, name=args.name, resource_type=args.resource_type, disabled=args.disabled, is_up=args.include_up) filters = {k: v for k, v in filters.items() if v is not None} if args.include_down and args.include_up: filters['is_up'] = None cleaning, unavailable = cs.work.clean(**filters) columns = ('ID', 'Name', 'State') if cleaning: print('Following nodes will be cleaned:') utils.print_list(cleaning, columns) if unavailable: print('There are no alternative nodes to do cleanup for:') utils.print_list(unavailable, columns) if not (cleaning or unavailable): print('No cleanable nodes matched cleanup criteria.')

commit_message:
Add Backup to cleanable resource types

Command `node-clean` only accepted "Volume" and "Snapshot" values for
--resource-type.

This patch adds "Backup" resource-type since they are now cleanable as
well.

Specs: https://review.openstack.org/236977
Patch in series: 4/5

Depends-On: Iadc26f20cdfea52d074723a46ec1e5f59853937e
Implements: blueprint cinder-volume-active-active-support
Change-Id: I6ceca7d8160d2f987bdde95d6da46e66a30fc7ce

added_lines: @utils.arg('--resource-type', metavar='<Volume|Snapshot|Backup>', default=None, choices=('Volume', 'Snapshot', 'Backup'),

revisions:

Volumes nodes will perform cleanup on start, but for cases when a node
doesn't come back up or doesn't have a passive node that will replace it
because we are using an Active/Active configuration Cinder has an auto
cleanup mechanism.

We can auto trigger this auto cleanup mechanism even when it is
disabled.

This patch adds the 'work-autoclean' command to trigger the auto cleanup
on the cloud.

New command: cinder work-autoclean

commit_message:
Add service node auto-cleanup

Volumes nodes will perform cleanup on start, but for cases when a node
doesn't come back up or doesn't have a passive node that will replace it
because we are using an Active/Active configuration Cinder has an auto
cleanup mechanism.

We can auto trigger this auto cleanup mechanism even when it is
disabled.

This patch adds the 'work-autoclean' command to trigger the auto cleanup
on the cloud.

This command will only work on servers with API version 3.4 or higher.

New command: cinder work-autoclean

Specs: https://review.openstack.org/236977
Patch in series: 5/5

Depends-On: Ib0f04b7d7bf85bc97dc9773bfdb0b082e18f0b08
Implements: blueprint cinder-volume-active-active-support
Change-Id: I5e2d4737abea292be668d15636827123d1cdaaeb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/38/304238/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _do_clean(method, **kwargs): cleaning, unavailable = method(**kwargs) columns = ('ID', 'Name', 'State') if cleaning: print('Following nodes will be cleaned:') utils.print_list(cleaning, columns) if unavailable: print('There are no alternative nodes to do cleanup for:') utils.print_list(unavailable, columns) if not (cleaning or unavailable): print('No cleanable nodes matched cleanup criteria.') _do_clean(cs.work.clean, **filters) def do_work_autoclean(cs, args): """Request auto cleanup of service nodes.""" _do_clean(cs.work.auto_clean)
deleted_lines: cleaning, unavailable = cs.work.clean(**filters) columns = ('ID', 'Name', 'State') if cleaning: print('Following nodes will be cleaned:') utils.print_list(cleaning, columns) if unavailable: print('There are no alternative nodes to do cleanup for:') utils.print_list(unavailable, columns) if not (cleaning or unavailable): print('No cleanable nodes matched cleanup criteria.')

commit_message:
Cleanup for Volume Object

Changed all occurrences of volume to object notation in the api.py
which don't require a change to the unit tests

All other occurrences which require change to unit tests will be
changed in another follow-up patch. This will help it easier to
review and improve readability

Change-Id: I83633d059270592ad98ecaa0934ab96114496af2
Partial-Implements: blueprint cinder-objects

commit_message:
Add backup import from file to cinderclient api

In order to be able to restore a volume backup on another
block storage, we need a command that will enable to import
a backup into the db from backup_metadata file.

Implements: blueprint cinder-backup-import-record-from-backup-metadata-file
Depends-on: I63075f38e551af943a671664a8951614d1b3849f

Conflicts:
	cinderclient/tests/unit/v3/test_shell.py
	cinderclient/v3/shell.py

Change-Id: I1f3e2d183a988959616efec442bc5948ee8da5bf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/79/292079/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import json@utils.arg('file_path', metavar='<file_path>', help='Import a volume backup from backup_metadata file.') @utils.service_type('volumev2') def do_backup_import_record_from_backup_metadata_file(cs, args): """Import backup metadata record from backup_metadata file.""" with open(args.file_path) as data_file: data = json.load(data_file) backup_url = data.get('extra_metadata').get('encode_record') backup_service = data.get('extra_metadata').get('driver_name') info = cs.backups.import_record(backup_service, backup_url) info.pop('links', None) utils.print_dict(info)

commit_message:
Add a hacking check stdlib logging rather than oslo.log

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/265559 fixed up the existing
cases. This check is added to prevent any new ones.

Change-Id: I60b5170ae1cbf969f77d3350f75998941847170e
Closes-bug: 1553865
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/70/289670/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(DuncanT): These files use logging rather than oslo.log intentionally SAFE_LOGGING_USERS = ['cinder/test.py'] import_logging = re.compile( r".*import logging$")def validate_no_import_logging(logical_line, filename): if re.match(import_logging, logical_line): for file in SAFE_LOGGING_USERS: if file in filename: return msg = ("C314: You should use oslo.log rather than logging") yield(0, msg) register(validate_no_import_logging)

commit_message:
Missing output in type-access-add

type-access-add operation does not return anything.
But for every create operation, cinder returns details
about operation like id, status etc.

This patchset will add details in output of type-access-add
operation.

Change-Id: I34dadff808622fe4a65b8e7c0ceda6212f0b7ac8
Closes-Bug:#1567376

commit_message:
Support for checking JSON format

This tool is required to check JSON syntax for cinder api-ref.

I need to clean API-ref for JSON formats..still in progress.
This tool will serve the purpose to verify after cleaning of
json format in existing api-ref json files.

Change-Id: I079c71b1ecb08fe63aa25beb68ccf27cdbda8e6e

commit_message:
Return multipath device from get_volume_paths

This only adresses the issue for the FC and iSCSI connectors. We will
now add the multipath paths onto the list that is returned.

Change-Id: Iaa5814e4bb25f552388a1ee94cd100ff80001231
Closes-Bug: #1577592
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/03/312203/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _discover_mpath_device_from_single_path(self, path, connection_properties): """Given a single path of the device find the mpath device.""" device_wwn = self._linuxscsi.get_scsi_wwn(path) LOG.debug("Device WWN = '%(wwn)s'", {'wwn': device_wwn}) (host_device, multipath_id) = self._discover_mpath_device( device_wwn, connection_properties, path) if host_device and multipath_id: return host_device if volume_paths and self.use_multipath: path = next(iter(volume_paths)) if path: mpath = (super(ISCSIConnector, self). _discover_mpath_device_from_single_path( path, connection_properties)) if mpath and mpath not in volume_paths: volume_paths.append(mpath) if volume_paths and self.use_multipath: path = next(iter(volume_paths)) if path: mpath = (super(FibreChannelConnector, self). _discover_mpath_device_from_single_path( path, connection_properties)) if mpath and mpath not in volume_paths: volume_paths.append(mpath)

commit_message:
Add configurable presentation delay to X-IO driver

This patch adds a delay to the X-IO driver in the
initialize_connection path. The delay is configurable
using the ise_present_wait option and is there to address
issues on some hosts that look for the connected device
before it has shown up in the OS. This has only been
seen on FC hosts.

DocImpact
Change-Id: I27b02647ca22ca388d1cbc6f46d80d1b6d76bb54
Closes-Bug: #1551023
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/01/287301/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014-2016 X-IO Technologies.import time cfg.IntOpt('ise_present_wait', default=1, help='Seconds to wait to let device show up on host.'), VERSION = '1.1.5' # 1.1.5 Add tuneable delay on presentation (Bug 1551023) # Wait a moment to allow device to show up on host time.sleep(self.configuration.ise_present_wait)

commit_message:
Ensure that lun_id is integer before use '&' operand

In case the lun_id is passed as string the _format_lun_id()
code fails. Check if the input is of type int, raise error
if not. Convert lun_id in process_lun_id() to int before
pass it as parameter to _format_lun_id(). Added new test case.

Closes-Bug: #1554184

Change-Id: If59f3df35549918bd5ddfeafc9141578ce28544a
Signed-off-by: Danny Al-Gaaf <danny.al-gaaf@bisect.de>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/01/291801/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if int(lun_id) < 256: return int(lun_id) (int(lun_id) & 0xffff, int(lun_id) >> 16 & 0xffff))

During volume migration, if the driver can provide the local
path for the source volume directly, there is no need to get
it via attaching the source volume.

the driver. If so, the local_path of the source volume will
be fetched directly.

During volume migration, if the driver can provide the local
path for the source volume directly, there is no need to get
it via attaching the source volume.

This patch adds a new config option sparse_copy_volume_data
for all the drivers and checks if the method local_path is
supported by the driver. If sparse_copy_volume_data is set
to True, the local_path of the source volume can be used to
copy the data of the volume.

Change-Id: I2ac243c630fb264652db6e96d27da1c9baf54bbf
Closes-Bug: #1520087
'}, {'number': 17, 'created': '2016-02-10 06:34:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/2d54fabd84f96a08ff3e559d79830e6624f159e1', 'message': 'Migration: take the local_path for the source volume

path for the source volume directly, there is no need to get
it via attaching the source volume.

This patch adds a new config option sparse_copy_volume_data
for all the drivers and checks if the method local_path is
supported by the driver. If sparse_copy_volume_data is set
to True, the local_path of the source volume can be used to
copy the data of the volume.

Change-Id: I2ac243c630fb264652db6e96d27da1c9baf54bbf

During volume migration, if the driver can provide the local

commit_message:
Migration: take the direct path for the source volume

During volume migration, if the driver can provide the direct
path for the source volume directly, there is no need to get
it via attaching the source volume.

This patch adds the implementation of the method
get_direct_volume_path to provide
the path, which can be used to access the volume data directly.
If this method returns None, there is no direct path available.
Otherwise, the path it returns can be used to access the volume
to copy the data. This patch takes LVM as the reference
implementation.

Change-Id: I2ac243c630fb264652db6e96d27da1c9baf54bbf
Closes-Bug: #1520087

is getting printed.

type-show command.

commit_message:
RBDClient: pass clustername and conffile to Rados

Read and forward the Ceph clustername and path to config file
to the os_brick rbd initiator to allow connection to clusters
with non-default names.

Extended existing test_connector test with new parameter.

Closes-Bug: #1563889

Change-Id: I904f47d49295547774da184b91befdd04cd8f861
Signed-off-by: Danny Al-Gaaf <danny.al-gaaf@bisect.de>
Co-Authored-By: Marc Fiedler <marc.fiedler@telekom.de>

commit_message:
support reset the state of consistency groups

The state of cg will be error when volumes to join cg fails.
Add reset-state API to support reset the state of cgs to the right
state.

Implements: bp reset-consistencygroup-state

Change-Id: Id60e0ce9386afa8c02f130d749d05df172edd753

added_lines: @wsgi.Controller.api_version("3.6") @wsgi.action('os-reset_status') def reset_status(self, req, id, body): """Reset the consistency group's status.""" LOG.debug('reset_status called for consistency group %s.', id) context = req.environ['cinder.context'] if not self.is_valid_body(body, 'os-reset_status'): msg = _("Missing required element 'os-reset_status' in " "request body.") raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg) cg_body = {} cg_body['status'] = body['os-reset_status'].get('status', 'available').lower() try: group = self.consistencygroup_api.get(context, id) self.consistencygroup_api.reset_status( context, group, cg_body) except exception.ConsistencyGroupNotFound as error: raise exc.HTTPNotFound(explanation=error.msg) except exception.InvalidInput as error: raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=error.msg) return webob.Response(status_int=202) member_actions={'delete': 'POST', 'update': 'PUT', 'action': 'POST'})

commit_message:
Add wraps function to sqlalchemy decorators

In order to preserve the docstring and function name the decorator
"wraps" is needed.

See:
https://docs.python.org/2/library/functools.html#functools.wraps

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I0dbbade2a4485a1640f8ce27b8de4048fd3134c5

commit_message:
Unify the type of value for what are True/False values

A bootable field in volume data returned from api
is a string data type.
However, a crypted field is a boolean data type.

The type of value which can be True or False should be boolean.

This issue is causing a another issue in horizon.
https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+bug/1587263

Change-Id: Idf9916f7cd5cd9bd941dcba1c626c662ea0493ff
Closes-Bug: #1589865
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/39/330339/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'bootable': False,

commit_message:
3PAR: Fix delete volume when online clone

When an online clone volume is deleted, the clone needs to be stopped
first. On delete, a new exception is raised from the 3PAR. We need to
check for the error code when hpeexceptions.HTTPConflict is raised.

Change-Id: I99020465455a4688b67e2fe1b4a9964616b3fcc1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/41/327841/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 3.0.55 - Fix delete volume when online clone is active VERSION = "2.0.55" elif ex.get_code() == 32: elif ex.get_code() == 151: if self.client.isOnlinePhysicalCopy(volume_name): LOG.debug("Found an online copy for %(volume)s", {'volume': volume_name}) # the volume is in process of being cloned. # stopOnlinePhysicalCopy will also delete # the volume once it stops the copy. self.client.stopOnlinePhysicalCopy(volume_name) else: # the volume is being operated on in a background # task on the 3PAR. # TODO(walter-boring) do a retry a few times. # for now lets log a better message msg = _("The volume is currently busy on the 3PAR" " and cannot be deleted at this time. " "You can try again later.") LOG.error(msg) raise exception.VolumeIsBusy(message=msg)

commit_message:
Add missing user message

Currently there is no message given by python cinderclient after
successfully accepting the request of delete snapshot and force delete
volume.To maintain consistency with other commands like delete volume
this message is added

Change-Id: Ia6933dd45f445fa312c5c64ca741dc2868aa4fa2
Closes-Bug: #1534060

commit_message:
Inherit multiattach from volume source

We should also update volume's mutiattach attribute when creating
from snapshot, source volume, or source replica. Currently the
created volume always set multiattach to False, even the source
snapshot/volume/replica/ is allowing multiattach.

This patch adds code to inherit multiattach from the source where
volume is created. The code is added in API layer so that I can
distinguish whether user has explicitly specified a multiattach
attribute. I didn't change API v1, because I think new feature
should only be added to newer version of APIs. I didn't see code to
create volume from source CG, so there is no multiattach inheriting
for that yet (If someone points that out I'm glad to change).

A new API microversion, 3.2, is also added.

APIImpact
Change-Id: I6a39d03108fd570af9095ffc7b1a0d9dd3a23830
Closes-Bug: #1505875

added_lines: # Load the snapshot's originating volume for later use if snapshot: try: snapshot_originating_volume = self.get_volume( context, snapshot.volume_id) except exception.VolumeNotFound: msg = _("Invalid snapshot provided: %(snapshot_id)s (cannot " "find the snapshot's originating volume: " "%(volume_id)s)") % {'snapshot_id': snapshot.id, 'volume_id': snapshot.volume_id} raise exception.InvalidInput(reason=msg) # If the volume is created from a source volume, replica or snapshot, # it inherits the source's multiattach attribute if source_volume: inherited_multiattach = source_volume.multiattach elif source_replica: inherited_multiattach = source_replica.multiattach elif snapshot: inherited_multiattach = snapshot_originating_volume.multiattach else: inherited_multiattach = False 'multiattach': multiattach or inherited_multiattach,

commit_message:
Closes Bug : 1493350
    Code Change to convert lunID/deviceID to hex as per SCSI report LUNs standard if greater than 255

Change-Id: I03c1742c4cb824b6e6a930ad995a32459eb7a65e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/71/264671/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """ Bug Fix : 143350 VinayP - Check is target lun is greater than 255 As per SCSI Report LUN's standard, if lun_id is > 255 the device by-path will be in hex format Therefore convert target_lun to hex if greater than 255 """ lun = 0 is_hex = re.compile( r'^0' '[xX]' '(0|' '([0-9A-Fa-f][0-9A-Fa-f]*))$' ).match if (not bool(is_hex(str(connection_properties['target_lun']))) and connection_properties['target_lun'] > 0xff): lun = ("0x%04x000000000000" % int(connection_properties['target_lun'])) LOG.info("target_lun %s converted to hex : %s for processing" "as per SCSI Report LUN standards" % (connection_properties['target_lun'], lun)) else: lun = connection_properties['target_lun'] lun)]

commit_message:
Updated volume, version, limit, metadata API-ref

Below changes are done in this patchset
1. Updated the index files.
2. Added missing api-extensions.inc.
3. updated parameters.yaml for all parameters used in inc files.
4. Fixed existing bug - Added 'bootable' filter in volume list.

Implements: bp api-reference-to-rst

Closes-Bug:#1536845

Change-Id: I02ad2372a564163916e802b3342dc9d551c7ba51

added_lines: .. -*- rst -*- =========================== API extensions (extensions) =========================== List API extensions =================== .. rest_method:: GET /v2/{tenant_id}/extensions Lists Block Storage API extensions. Normal response codes: 200, 300 Request Example --------------- .. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - tenant_id: tenant_id Response Parameters ------------------- .. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - name: name - description: description - namespace: namespace - alias: alias - links: links - updated: updated Response Example ---------------- .. literalinclude:: ./samples/extensions-list-response.json :language: javascript This operation does not accept a request body.

commit_message:
Fix wrong volume type of restore action

Automatically restore volume to its original type when a dest
volume_id is not specified. If the original type has already
been deleted, fallback to a default volume type.

APIImpact

Change-Id: Ic8a25fc9daeca0db1642358a918aecfd961b1989
Closes-Bug: #1567263

commit_message:
Add max-width feature to limit the width of the printed table

Sometimes the output of the printed table is not friendly readable.
Especially for the *-show commands since the detail information
usually includes many words, for instance [1].

For more user-friendly format, we'd better add a max-width feature
to limit the width of the column(0 by default which means unlimited).

In this patch, we only consider the *-show commands.

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/497826/

Change-Id: I3977b63a203c2e443ed7baf5d357bfac5af145f5

commit_message:
WIP: Update LVM code so nova can use it

This patch is a WIP

The purpose of this patch is to reconcile the differences between
the lvm.py code in brick already with the Nova lvm.py code, so that Nova
can use brick's lvm code for managing LVM groups and volumes.

Change-Id: I39e7e6ddc9bd9951fa10017025e5110fa705ee0f

added_lines: from os_brick.i18n import _, _LE, _LI, _LW from os_brick.initiator import linuxscsifrom oslo_utils import unitsVOLUME_TYPE_DEFAULT = 'default' VOLUME_TYPE_THIN = 'thin' VOLUME_SIZE_UNITS_BYTES = 'b' VOLUME_SIZE_UNITS_GIGABYTES = 'g' CLEAR_TYPE_SHRED = 'shred' CLEAR_TYPE_ZERO = 'zero' CLEAR_TYPE_NONE = 'none' """Get logical volume info. :param path: logical volume path :returns: Return a dict object including info of given logical volume : Data format example : {'#Seg': '1', 'Move': '', 'Log': '', 'Meta%': '', : 'Min': '-1', 'Free': '9983', 'LV': 'volume-aaa', : 'Host': 'xyz.com', 'Active': 'active', : 'Path': '/dev/vg/volume-aaa', '#LV': '3', : 'Maj': '-1', 'VSize': '50.00g', 'VFree': '39.00g', : 'Pool': '', 'VG Tags': '', 'KMaj': '253', 'Convert': '', : 'LProfile': '', : '#Ext': '12799', 'Attr': '-wi-a-----', 'VG': 'vg', : 'LSize': '1.00g', '#PV': '1', '#VMdaCps': 'unmanaged'} cmd = LVM.LVM_CMD_PREFIX + ['lvs', '--unit=g', '-o', 'vg_all,lv_all', '--nosuffix', '--separator', '|'] out, err = putils.execute(*cmd, root_helper=root_helper, run_as_root=True) if out: info = [line.split('|') for line in out.splitlines()] # strip out the header, so we can use it multiple times # also convert the keys to all lower case. header = [key.lower() for key in info[0]] info.pop(0) for vol in info: # create a list, that contains the header and volume info # zip them together as a single dictionary # and add that to the volume list # for Cinder backwards compatibility we create name and size # from the standard lv and vsize vol_dict = dict(zip(*[header, vol])) vol_dict['name'] = vol_dict['lv'] vol_dict['size'] = vol_dict['lsize'] # for Nova backwards compatibility, we create VG and LV vol_dict['LV'] = vol_dict['lv'] vol_dict['VG'] = vol_dict['vg'] lv_list.append(vol_dict) vg_name=self.vg_name, lv_name=lv_name) ref_list = self.get_volumes(lv_name=name) for r in ref_list: if r['lv'] == name: def get_all_physical_volumes(root_helper, vg_name=None, units=VOLUME_SIZE_UNITS_GIGABYTES): '--unit=%s' % units, def get_all_volume_groups(root_helper, vg_name=None, units=VOLUME_SIZE_UNITS_GIGABYTES): '--unit=%s' % units, '-o', def create_volume(self, name, size_str, lv_type=VOLUME_TYPE_DEFAULT, mirror_count=0): @staticmethod def get_volume_size(path, root_helper): """Get logical volume size in bytes. :param path: logical volume path :raises: processutils.ProcessExecutionError if getting the volume size fails in some unexpected way. :raises: exception.VolumePathNotFound if the volume path does not exist. """ scsi = linuxscsi.LinuxSCSI(root_helper) return scsi.get_device_size(path) def clear_volume(self, path, volume_clear_size=0, clear_type=CLEAR_TYPE_SHRED): """Obfuscate the contents of a volume. :param path: logical path of the volume on the system :param volume_clear_size: clear only this amount of the volume. None means clear the entire volume. :param clear_type: use shred or dd to nuke the volume. Defaults to using shred. """ if clear_type == CLEAR_TYPE_NONE: return try: volume_size = LVM.get_volume_size(path, self._root_helper) except exception.VolumeDeviceNotFound: LOG.warning(_LW("ignoring missing logical volume %(path)s"), {'path': path}) return if not volume_clear_size: # we don't have a size to clear, # so lets clear the entire volume clear_size = volume_size elif volume_clear_size < volume_size: clear_size = volume_clear_size if clear_type == CLEAR_TYPE_ZERO: # NOTE(p-draigbrady): we could use shred to do the zeroing # with -n0 -z, however only versions >= 8.22 perform as well as # dd LVM.zero_volume(path, clear_size) elif clear_type == CLEAR_TYPE_SHRED: try: self._execute('shred', '-n3', '-s%d' % clear_size, path, root_helper=self._root_helper, run_as_root=True) except putils.ProcessExecutionError as err: LOG.exception(_LE('Error clearing volume with shred')) LOG.error(_LE('Cmd :%s'), err.cmd) LOG.error(_LE('StdOut :%s'), err.stdout) LOG.error(_LE('StdErr :%s'), err.stderr) raise def _zero_volume(self, path, volume_size): """Write zeros over the specified path. :param path: logical volume path :param size: number of zeros to write """ bs = units.Mi direct_flags = ('oflag=direct',) sync_flags = () remaining_bytes = volume_size # The loop efficiently writes zeros using dd, # and caters for versions of dd that don't have # the easier to use iflag=count_bytes option. while remaining_bytes: zero_blocks = remaining_bytes / bs seek_blocks = (volume_size - remaining_bytes) / bs zero_cmd = ('dd', 'bs=%s' % bs, 'if=/dev/zero', 'of=%s' % path, 'seek=%s' % seek_blocks, 'count=%s' % zero_blocks) zero_cmd += direct_flags zero_cmd += sync_flags if zero_blocks: utils.execute(*zero_cmd, run_as_root=True) remaining_bytes %= bs bs /= units.Ki # Limit to 3 iterations # Use O_DIRECT with initial block size and fdatasync otherwise direct_flags = () sync_flags = ('conv=fdatasync',)

commit_message:
remove redundant image fetch

When creating volume from image, it makes redundant image fetch
even if option 'image_volume_cache' is disabled. optimization
should be made to improve the performance of volume-creating.
This patch is to fix the problem.

Change-Id: I3f0e6e461d987520b1502fee436d8b90774712ca
Closes-Bug: #1594299

commit_message:
LVM+tgt:iscsi target deleted after VM live migrate

Cinder_volume does not check whether there are connections before
excutes 'tgt-admin --force --delete' in the func
'remove_iscsi_target'. That leads to iscsi target be removed after
detach volume.

Change-Id: I299d369d0605d631d0dd7bf983fcd8bb15504861
Closes-Bug: #1477831

commit_message:
Use "image" as argument for Glance V1 upload error path

In Glance V1 the argument is "image", not "image_id", so use this on
the error path to cleanup.

Change-Id: Ie64e2911798cef17f1263d961d70f7715b2ba64b

commit_message:
Fix the ansible-func-centos-7-nv test

The ansible-func-centos-7-nv test fails because the package names for
dependencies are different in CentOS than Ubuntu.

This adds specific packages for dpkg and rpm based systems.

Change-Id: I2ab79fed6ec838d2302edc855957bb48d5178932

commit_message:
Fix create_volume_from_snapshot in Huawei driver

In create_volume_from_snapshot function, there's
no 'provider_location' in return values. And it
leads detach snapshot volume failed on the array.
This bug is only exists in liberty. So fix it on
stable/liberty.

Change-Id: I784b0b0962cae7ccd31f953b29ba8992774159ca
Closes-Bug: #1541234

commit_message:
RBD: delete snapshots if missing in the backend

snapshot delete should be more robust to also handle backend errors.
In case the backend does not have the image snapshot anymore,
log an info message and succeed the operation.
A first attempt to fix this problem was found on
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/151257/
This patch is already merged but it does not fix the problem
completely.

Closes-Bug: #1415905
(cherry picked from commit 677eb1c4160c08cfce2900495741f0ea15f566fa)

Change-Id: I51b0f5bb2bb60144dace79ebed06a66aaeb54574

commit_message:
Verify if snapshot is already managed

Currenly in lvm, snapshot id is verified from volume db entries
to confirm if snapshot being managed is already managed by cinder
or not.
But that will always return false.
So, this check is wrong and should be modified to verify against
snapshot db entries.
Added method to check if snapshot is already managed while snapshot
manage operation.

Change-Id: I591905c8afd447490c709b44c63255c10edef875
Closes-Bug: #1525887
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/23/314923/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Allow API user to update multiattach attr of volume

This change allow API user to update the ``multiattach``
attr of a volume. User can update this attr of a volume which
in status 'available', otherwise an exception of InvalidVolume
is returned.

APIImpact

Closes-Bug: #1572996
Change-Id: Iafc4bf67b67a3ec9149f824d7fe16b8bdc116835

commit_message:
Backup and restore broken in zfssaiscsi driver

Volume backup and restore functionality in the iscsi driver needs
to fall back on the base driver's implementation.
This fix is for the driver in Liberty and needs to be backported.

Change-Id: I3f2751a89241a7779c964746dc815dd9b23ef40b
Closes-Bug: #1591332
(cherry picked from commit c68892af439c1365e2708ed7ad532a0b46b7f5a0)

commit_message:
The LVM backend Consistency Group Support

This patch adds consistency group to support for the LVM volume driver.

implements blueprint lvm-cg-support

Change-Id: I952dc9e525a85371ff4c59fa4efb43a5c791aae2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/49/323649/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinder.objects import fields multiattach=True, consistencygroup_support='True' def create_consistencygroup(self, context, group): """Create a consistency group. """ LOG.debug("Creating consistency group") model_update = {'status': fields.ConsistencyGroupStatus.AVAILABLE} return model_update def delete_consistencygroup(self, context, group, volumes): """Deletes a consistency group and volumes in the group.""" model_update = {'status': group['status']} volume_model_updates = [] for volume in volumes: volume_model_update = {'id': volume['id']} try: self.remove_export(context, volume) self.delete_volume(volume) volume_model_update['status'] = 'deleted' except Exception as e: LOG.error(_LE("Delete consistencygroup failed due to " "exception: %(reason)s."), {'reason': six.text_type(e)}, resource=volume) volume_model_update['status'] = 'error_deleting' model_update['status'] = \ fields.ConsistencyGroupStatus.ERROR_DELETING volume_model_updates.append(volume_model_update) return model_update, volume_model_updates def create_cgsnapshot(self, context, cgsnapshot, snapshots): """Creates a cgsnapshot.""" model_update = {'status': 'available'} snapshot_model_updates = [] for snapshot in snapshots: snapshot_model_update = {'id': snapshot['id']} try: self.create_snapshot(snapshot) snapshot_model_update['status'] = 'available' except Exception as e: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): LOG.error(_LE("Create cgsnapshot failed due to " "exception: %(reason)s."), {'reason': six.text_type(e)}, resource=snapshot) self.delete_snapshot(snapshot) snapshot_model_updates.append(snapshot_model_update) return model_update, snapshot_model_updates def delete_cgsnapshot(self, context, cgsnapshot, snapshots): """Deletes a cgsnapshot.""" model_update = {'status': cgsnapshot['status']} snapshot_model_updates = [] for snapshot in snapshots: snapshot_model_update = {'id': snapshot['id']} try: self.delete_snapshot(snapshot) snapshot_model_update['status'] = 'deleted' except Exception as e: LOG.error(_LE("Create cgsnapshot failed due to " "exception: %(reason)s."), {'reason': six.text_type(e)}, resource=snapshot) snapshot_model_update['status'] = 'error_deleting' model_update['status'] = 'error_deleting' snapshot_model_updates.append(snapshot_model_update) return model_update, snapshot_model_updates def create_consistencygroup_from_src(self, context, group, volumes, cgsnapshot=None, snapshots=None, soure_cg=None, source_vols=None): """Creates a consistencygroup from cgsnapshot or source cg.""" model_update = {'status': fields.ConsistencyGroupStatus.AVAILABLE} volume_model_updates = [] if cgsnapshot and snapshots: for volume, snapshot in zip(volumes, snapshots): volume_model_update = {'id': volume['id']} try: self.create_volume_from_snapshot(volume, snapshot) volume_model_update['status'] = 'available' except Exception as e: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): LOG.error(_LE("Create consistencygroup failed due to " "exception: %(reason)s."), {'reason': six.text_type(e)}, resource=volume) self.delete_volume(volume) volume_model_updates.append(volume_model_update) elif soure_cg and source_vols: for volume, source_vol in zip(volumes, source_vols): volume_model_update = {'id': volume['id']} try: self.create_cloned_volume(volume, source_vol) volume_model_update['status'] = 'available' except Exception as e: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): LOG.error(_LE("Create consistencygroup failed due to " "exception: %(reason)s."), {'reason': six.text_type(e)}, resource=volume) self.delete_volume(volume) volume_model_updates.append(volume_model_update) return model_update, volume_model_updates def update_consistencygroup(self, context, group, add_volumes=None, remove_volumes=None): """Updates a consistency group.""" return None, None, None

commit_message:
Add a base attribute 'id' for resources

This patch will add a new base attribute 'id',
which means resource_id of the resource. And for this
attribute we don't have to get from other services by api.

Change-Id: I217388486a77aa7c8dfe2309a818f07d2191a793
Closes-Bug: #1613958

commit_message:
Add debug logging to revocation event checking

Previously, the revocation matching engine was basically a black box
that seemed to mysteriously match some tokens and not others, and it was
difficult to understand why an event would match a given token at a
glance. Fixed.

Change-Id: I751d891dc1cec2bb22ad6a3948aafaa34fc835d1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/42/353742/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: A brute force approach to checking. Compare each attribute from the event with the corresponding value from the token. If the event does not have a value for the attribute, a match is still possible. If the event has a value for the attribute, and it does not match the token, no match is possible, so skip the remaining checks. # If any one check does not match, the whole token does not match the # event. The numerous return False indicate that the token is still valid # and short-circuits the rest of the logic. LOG.debug('Comparing token to revocation event: %s', event.id) LOG.debug('The user ID in the revocation event does not match any ' 'user IDs in the token.') LOG.debug('The domain ID in the revocation event does not match any ' 'domain IDs in the token.') LOG.debug('The domain scope ID in the revocation event does not match ' 'the domain scope ID in the token.') LOG.debug('The project ID in the revocation event does not match ' 'the project ID in the token.') LOG.debug('The expiration in the revocation event does not match ' 'the expiration of the token.') LOG.debug('The trust ID in the revocation event does not match ' 'the trust ID in the token.') LOG.debug('The OAuth consumer ID in the revocation event does not ' 'match the OAuth consumer ID in the token.') LOG.debug('The OAuth access token ID in the revocation event does not ' 'match the OAuth access token ID in the token.') LOG.debug('The audit ID in the revocation event does not match the ' 'audit ID in the token.') LOG.debug('The audit chain ID in the revocation event does not match ' 'the audit chain ID in the token.') LOG.debug('The role ID in the revocation event does not match ' 'any of the role IDs in the token.') LOG.debug('The revocation event was issued before the token was ' 'created.') LOG.debug('All attributes in the revocation event are in the token.')
deleted_lines: A brute force approach to checking. Compare each attribute from the event with the corresponding value from the token. If the event does not have a value for the attribute, a match is still possible. If the event has a value for the attribute, and it does not match the token, no match is possible, so skip the remaining checks. # If any one check does not match, the whole token does # not match the event. The numerous return False indicate # that the token is still valid and short-circuits the # rest of the logic.

commit_message:
Add info about ports to sf_svip config entry

The SolidFire config ref was updated to include the requirement
of specifying sf_svip in the config file when using vlans,
however the update doesn't mention the fact that when specifying
this option the admin MUST also include the port number in the ip.

So rather than just "10.5.3.4" it must be of the form "10.5.3.4:3260".

The mitaka release (forward) will automatically append a default
port number in the driver, but that's not available in Liberty.

This patch just updates the Liberty docs to point out that port
number is required in the argument.

Change-Id: I25b4432df63831a42921ed28dab1699f321562a0
Closes-Bug: #1614243
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/85/356685/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: (StrOpt) Overrides default cluster SVIP with the one specified. This is required or deployments that have implemented the use of VLANs for iSCSI networks in their cloud. Usage of this flag requires inclusion of the port address; example 10.10.0.8:3260
deleted_lines: (StrOpt) Overrides default cluster SVIP with the one specified. This is required or deployments that have implemented the use of VLANs for iSCSI networks in their cloud.

commit_message:
Replaced the term "tenant" with "project"

This patch avoids the mismatch between the legacy term tenant and
the future term project by replacing the term tenant with project.

This is a partial fix and the further patches will completely
remove the term "tenant" from the documentation to avoid any kind
of confusion.

Change-Id: I52adfa5831f504145c2f6f0018062c818518633f
Partial-Bug: #1475005
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/77/356377/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

If no project is specified in the API request, Compute attempts to use a project with the same ID as the user. For projects, you can use quota controls to limit the:A project limits users' access to particular images. Each user isproject can control resource consumption across available hardware Earlier versions of OpenStack used the term ``tenant`` instead of ``project``. Update the home-page info with the developer documentation

Since there are so many components in openstack,
by describing the URL info in the configuration file,
it is more convenient to find the developer documentation
than from the unified portal

commit_message:
Update page title on job and test pages

This commit adds page title updates to the job and test pages using
the pageTitleService. Currently these pages only show "Job" or "Test"
in the title bar, but this sets the title to "Job: current-job" or
"Test: current-test" depending on the current page.

Change-Id: I8bae8d6e47cdcfbdef18314d20b4d313f7e2e5ca
Closes-Bug: #1614076

commit_message:
Correct the get_file patch in CoreOS template

In CoreOS templates, the pathes provided to get_file has a extra 's'.
This caused an error on creating CoreOS bay.

Change-Id: I8d49df913fc169ce573365c5ca485cb56806e49e
Closes-Bug: #1611065

commit_message:
Add support for master elected component

For k8s bay in HA mode, current all master components are active.
Added support for master elected component to ensure only one
master component is active. This will enhance the concurrency
controller.

Change-Id: I8a5489df0878a384a38bf755851c98b170282a1f
Closes-Bug: #1504681

subject: Remove deb-websockify from projects.yaml
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-17 22:37:38.000000000', 'files': ['gerrit/projects.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/dbe0206ceb6376a85f105af0658327a53f3992cf', 'message': "Remove deb-websockify from projects.yaml

The upstream deb-websockify repo is corrupt in a manner that gerrit/jgit
won't accept its objects. Specifically:

  warning in tree 7a80ca084167b04a732640a2f18ec86af55377fb:
  zeroPaddedFilemode: contains zero-padded file modes

This means we can't populate the repo properly which in turn breaks our
image builds when they try to clone and cache this repo. Work around
that for now until the upstream repo can be corrected by removing it
from projects.yaml.

For more information on how to fix repos in this state see:
https://www.perforce.com/blog/150109/git-out-vulnerability-out-fire but
tl:dr is run:

  git fast-export --all | (cd ../myFixedRepo; git fast-import)

Change-Id: I95c9bd5088c5c02440fbf15cd588884b5e0dd954
"}]
commit_message:
Remove deb-websockify from projects.yaml

The upstream deb-websockify repo is corrupt in a manner that gerrit/jgit
won't accept its objects. Specifically:

  warning in tree 7a80ca084167b04a732640a2f18ec86af55377fb:
  zeroPaddedFilemode: contains zero-padded file modes

This means we can't populate the repo properly which in turn breaks our
image builds when they try to clone and cache this repo. Work around
that for now until the upstream repo can be corrected by removing it
from projects.yaml.

For more information on how to fix repos in this state see:
https://www.perforce.com/blog/150109/git-out-vulnerability-out-fire but
tl:dr is run:

  git fast-export --all | (cd ../myFixedRepo; git fast-import)

Change-Id: I95c9bd5088c5c02440fbf15cd588884b5e0dd954
